is a bustling, friendly hill station, and the capital of the Himalayan state of
is derived from the Tibetan word for 'hillside,' and the city currently has a population of around 80,000 - a mixture of indigenous Sikkimese and people of Nepalese and Tibetan ancestry.

Gangtok is popular place with tourists heading on treks, though the facilities do not reflect the number of international visitors. However, efforts are being made by the government to improve the conditions. Gangtok would be easily one of the most cleanest cities you would ever come across, highly organized and beautifully maintained it the Switzerland of the east. Tourists are of paramount importance, hence rules have been laid in order to prevent tourists from being cheated. Fares of Cabs are mostly fixed for such reason. 
A really nice place to unwind. Quite a few places for vegetarians to eat since it is mostly dominated by Buddhist culture. The city resembles the Bhutanese capital. Devoid of large stores, book shops this place is an nice break away from typical city lives. Still, the city is a fascinating place to spend a few nights, the winding side alleys hide some unexpected gems, and the main street (MG Marg) is pedestrianized and a pleasant place to take a stroll.

The city sleeps by 9 pm mostly, except for a few pubs which are open till 11 pm.

The best season to Visit Gangtok is Jan-March.
The nearest airport is at Bagdogra (IXB) at a distance of roughly 120 kilometers. The Bagdogra airport (14 kms from

) is served by direct flights from Kolkata and New Delhi. From airport you can hire a taxi or cab to reach at Gangtok. Frequent direct flights are also available for Bagdogra and a lovely highway passing through beautiful scenery, waterfall and mountains will take you to the Gangtok. A helicopter flies between the Bagdogra and Gangtok once a day around 2.00PM and requires pre -booking, as it carries only 8 passengers.
The nearest train station to Gangtok is New Jalpaiguri in

, and other major cities in India. It is a 10-12 hour journey from Kolkata.

Once you arrive in New Jalpaiguri, you can either hire a taxi from the station itself or take an auto-rickshaw to the Siliguri bus stand. From there, you have the option of travelling to Gangtok by state bus, roughly a 5-6 hour journey.

Dozens of jeeps travel to Gangtok daily from

, and other mountain locales.
Fare of the shared cabs is generally fixed, it is around Rs.155 to Gangtok from NJP station. Drivers might try to charge high so check for the fare with other cabs before taking one. Approx. 95 kms distance gets covered between 2-3 hours. It may take longer as the road conditions area bad.

value: Taxis ply routes around the city, and there are standard charges within the main areas: Rs 40 for a private service and Rs 8 for a shared. NB: Taxis can only be hailed from designated taxi stands.
Private Taxis are also available at Lal Market and MG Marg. Taxis do not run on meter basis, so you can negotiate for right fare before boarding.

Private and SNT buses are available for intercity travelling. For places like Tashiding, Yuksom and Pelling buses depart from 7 AM and 12:30 PM from SNT bus stop. Hourly services are also available for some places like Jorethang, Namchi, Ravangla and Geyzing.
Kanchenjunga seen from Tashi View Point
- there are beautiful views of the surrounding hills from the town itself, but the best views - dominated by
, the world's third-highest mountain - are from
is the best view point from where you can see the Mount Kanchenjunga.
- a two hundred year old monastery in the Nyingma tradition of Tibetan Buddhism - located above the town.
- a large and impressive stupa complex constructed in 1945.
. A large monastery in the Nyingma tradition. Famous for its large chorten. When in residence, Dodrupchen Rinpoche receives devotees to offer blessings from around 8AM to 9:30AM.

content=Near the White-Hall, flower show is at its best during the flowering season which is mid March to end of May in spring and October to mid December in autumn. But by far the annual Cymbidium Orchid Show wnich commences invariably from mid March to mid April is the best and the finest in the entire south Asian region.
:- The road will be bustling with the travelers. The road is meant only for pedestrians no vehicles allowed. The Road is full of flowers,orchids and fountains.Nice and Clam Walk.
. An excellent collection of artifacts and manuscripts connected to Tibetan Buddhism.
content= It's a lovely waterfall, surrounded by gardens and stairwells. Many beautiful sculptures can be seen there. A good picnic spot and a must watch for every Gangtok visitor.
hours=Daylight. Can close due to weather

content=A cable car whose lowest point is Deorali Market, with three stops of varying altitude. Fantastic views of the town.  This isn't included in official tours, so you'll have to make your way to Deorali Market to board.

Sikkim is famous for its fruit processing and tea aside from the local handicraft.Passion fruit Squash, Alpine Cheese, Temi Tea & Maha Gurudev Tea are some of the local products.

value: content=Development Area. (www.rachnabooks.com). Also organises events and exhibitions on The First Floor upstairs. By far the best
in town. A wide selection of titles and knowledgable owner. Rachna is located about a ten minute walk from the main bazaar.
content=Below Hotel Mayur, PS Road (just above the main hospital). One of the better quality handicraft stores in town. Excellent selection of Buddhist artwork.
content=Good place to buy prayer wheels, flags and other handicraft. Little expensive.
name=The Wayside Gardens & Nurseries Pvt. Ltd.

content= Well known House of exotic plants including Orchids. Azaleas and Cattleya hybrid orchids, besides range of Citrus, are their specialities. A must visit place for any plant lover. Run by illustrious Pradhan family. Visit stricty by prior appointment. Conducted tour in the well spread out Garden for groups conducted by Travel Agents and interactions about Himalayan flora with Sr. Pradhan, authority on Himalayan flora and environment, over cup of tea on payment of nominal fee, possible.  Contact person: Sailesh Pradhan. Mobile: 98320 60555.

There are many great and cheap places to eat in Gangtok.

value: (Mahatma Gandhi Marg, about 3/4 of the walk away from the Tourist Information Center to the far end of the central pedestrian promenade, on the right side). A cultural relic not to be missed, this fast food outlet located in a wooden hut (perhaps the last traditional building surviving in the remodelled central area) serves a rigorous menu consisting of 2 items: beef momos (Tibetan dumplings) and beef noodle soup. The food is completely devoid of spices and salt. Chili paste, soy sauce and salt are provided as side condiments. The building is somewhat skewed and may present safety hazards, but it appears to have survived generations of customers, and the upper floor offers an agreeable view.  An antique portrait of Dalai Lama XIV around the age of 30 graces the front counter. Visit this one before it has been replaced by another McDonald's, or (better still) try to do something to save it from impending destruction.
, on MG Marg down a short flight of stairs, serves some of the best food in town, and is very popular with locals.

, tucked on the side of a stairway between MG Marg and the main market, serves up Veg Momos & hot chapatis (Roll)with various fillings (paneer, egg, veggies).  This place is always packed with both tourists and locals and deservedly so.
, and numerous other sweet shops up and down MG Marg, serve up everything from samosas to momos.
address=Chumbi Residency, Tibet Road, Gangtok-737101, Sikkim.
content=Stunning food, some unusual options and
cheaper than it ought to be.
content=Serves south Indian and north Indian snacks and sweets. Good place to have breakfast. There are two outlets, one on MG Marg and other on the way near the taxi stand. Dosas are not so good.
content=Authentic Tibetan and Indo-Chinese fusion cuisine. The Beef/ Pork chilli , the momos and the tea momos are recommended.

content=An upscale pub right in the heart of MG Road. Great drinks, tasty food (especially the Malai Tikka and Sauteed Mushrooms), and an amazing ambiance. The price is higher than other pubs on the street, but its definitely worth it.
content=Serves Tibetan food, thupkas, gyathuk and thentuk. It includes a bar too.
content=On the way up towards the Zero point, left side. Run by a Tibetan, serves very good coffee. Eatables are just decent. Coffee is way better than baker's cafe.
content=The only place in town to sell cappuccino, latte and offer a wide selection of Western-style pastries. Check out the pizzas.
address=Ground Floor, Hotel Pandim, Secretariat Road

content=Located at the ridge which is an ideal location for walk and best view of the mountain, the cafe offers fresh Himalayan cuisine like phale( local bread), shiafale ( local bread filled with meat and deep fried), momos and grilled sandwiches.

content=Phone: (03592) 207540 (Cell: +91 98320 80172, ). A family run guest house with the best location, just above the Mall Road and below the Royal Palace offering the best mountain view. Also has a nice cafe called Cafe Culture offering fresh Himalayan cuisine.

content=Phone: (033) 2552 3432 / 2584 0080 (Cell: +91 98302 87429, ). A nice place for budget tourists and a good base to meet other travellers - recently relocated to the main town near the Tourist Information Centre. It also organizes tours throughout Sikkim.

, (Cell: +91 98323 48837), A nice place for budget tourists and just above the popular MG Marg. Fair rooms and nice good food. Wise to book in per person per day format inclusive of fooding & loadging. It also organizes tours throughout Sikkim.

content=A nice place for Budget tourists and a good base to meet other travellers -  recently relocated to the main town near the Tourist Information Centre. It also organizes tours throughout Sikkim.
content=Bamboo Grove, Kazi Road. A Boutique 2 star hotel.
= Car Parking, Peaceful Environment, Internet, Mountain View from Rooms, Mountain Biking, Bar & Restaurant.
, Paljor Stadium Road. Clean and comfortable rooms with an excellent restaurant. Rs.1500-2500.
Libing Complex, M.G.Marg & Nam Nam Crossing, above Star Cinema Hall.
content=Church Road. Conveniently located, warm, elegant decor and excellent service. Rs 1,200+ per night.
Hotel Golden nest & Hotel Hill View

, Tibet Road. An awesome hotel for the money. The facilities are best of Gangtok. The standard room (Rs 1100) is spartan; the super-deluxe (Rs 2200) is well-furnished and has an excellent view of the hillside. All facilities are very neatly maintained. The staff's knowledge of English is poor, but you can get by. No south-Indian food, though.
content=Five star deluxe resort, spread over 15 acres of lush forest, some of the villas with temperature controlled dip pools.
content= Unit of Elgin Hotels and Resorts. Colonial decor and luxury at its best.

content=Situated near the Rumtek Monastery about 20 km from the town. Spread over 6 acres with its own garden and organic farming. 12 rooms spread over 5 cottages. 4 Suite Rooms and 8 Deluxe Cottages, with Ethnic Nepali style.
content=Colour TV, carpeted rooms.Staff was very kind and helpful.And Worth Money.

It is not an exaggeration but Gangtok, Sikkim is really one of the safest places for women. However, the standard rules of safety like being alert from strangers and not to hang out in desert places are applicable to everyone.

If you are traveling alone then it is advisable to take hotel in Gangtok itself and not in remote area.
 
The roads in Gangtok are not properly intact and sometimes main highway remains close due to frequent landslides, so a word of cautious is given for non-experience drivers.

No Plastics carry bags sold or used.

Spitting, littering or smoking in public areas of Sikkim is a punishable offence and can lead you to a serious amount of fine. Streets in sikkim have bins to throw garbage and spit. 

Don't hurt religious sentiments of local people or else they will revert back strongly.

Don't humiliate local people because of their clumsy appearance as economical condition of Gangtok's inhabitants is not that good and tourism is the only medium by which Gangtok will become financially strong.

There area no internet cafes along the main thoroughfares and the rate is compatible with other centers of commerce in India. However, the infrastructure is weak, and the mantra of most internet cafes is 'server down.' Travelers who need to work extensively on the internet are advised to do so in Siliguri, where the server connection is much more reliable.

value: , tucked away just after the first pedestrian bridge up from the old taxi station, this
offers two rooms filled with computers with fast connections.
Gangtok serves as an excellent base for visiting places like
. One of the most important Tibetan Buddhist monasteries, and head seat of the Karma Kagyu school in Sikkim. Originally built in 1740, it fell into disrepair. The current structure dates from 1959.

, (near Rumtek) is a small, friendly, family run hotel. To reach Rumtek one can hire an taxi. There are share taxi's which run from MG Marg taxi stand to Rumtek. One way fare is around Rs. 30 per person. It is a cheaper alternative but you need to return from the Rumtek Monastery before 4pm to get shared taxi to MG Marg again.
Ranka monastery is a newly built monastery and a treat to watch out for.
Ask around travel agents as they sometimes field requests from travellers looking to share jeeps to cut costs. It's an excellent way to meet people too.
